Simulation Log

Click on the buttons to see the detailed logs:

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Lennon Figtree']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Lennon Figtree -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Della Plumstone is at the Fruitville market trying to buy fruit from Lennon Figtree to resell in her hometown for a profit.

        • Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 12 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Della Plumstone is at the Fruitville market trying to buy fruit from Lennon Figtree to resell in her hometown for a profit.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Della Plumstone? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation??
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a quirky and imaginative inventor.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Della Plumstone in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a renowned archaeologist, currently excavating a mysterious temple in the Amazon rainforest.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Della Plumstone to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Della Plumstone sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a talented pastry chef with a dream of opening her own bakery.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she convinced the village children that a patch of wild berries were enchanted, capable of granting wishes. She charged them each a shiny pebble for a handful, pocketing a small fortune in trinkets.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she discovered a crate of bruised apples behind the village market. She cleaned them, arranged them artfully, and sold them as a rare, exotic variety to unsuspecting housewives.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she overheard a traveling merchant boasting about a chest full of jewels. That night, she swapped the jewels with cleverly painted pebbles, leaving the merchant none the wiser until he reached the next town.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she set up her first fruit stall at a bustling market. She charmed customers with tall tales about the origins of her produce, selling ordinary apples and pears at exorbitant prices.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she traveled to a distant city, her cart laden with fruit. She invented a story about a rare orchard, hidden deep in a forest, where the fruit possessed magical properties.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is a fruit seller in the village of Fruitville, where he is currently negotiating a price for peaches with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could accept Della Plumstone's offer of four coins, try to negotiate a higher price, or walk away from the deal.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to try to negotiate a higher price.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00]
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they wandered away from their father's stall at the market, captivated by a troupe of travelling performers. He was mesmerized by their colorful costumes, their booming voices, and the way they could weave stories that transported him to faraway lands. From that day forward, Lennon began to see the world as a stage, and himself as a potential performer.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they discovered a hidden grove of wild berries, their plumpness bursting with sweetness. He carefully picked the ripest ones, arranging them into a beautiful display before offering them to his father. His father, impressed by Lennon's keen eye and entrepreneurial spirit, gave him a small pouch of coins, sparking a lifelong passion for the art of buying and selling.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they overheard two merchants arguing over the price of a crate of oranges. He listened intently, absorbing the nuances of their negotiation, the subtle shifts in tone, and the unspoken power dynamics at play. That night, he practiced haggling with his father, honing his skills and discovering a knack for persuasion.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their father to let them travel to a neighboring town to sell their own fruit. He meticulously planned his route, carefully selecting the ripest mangoes and peaches, and crafting a captivating story about their origin. The success of his first solo venture filled him with a sense of accomplishment and ignited a desire for independence.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they fell deeply in love with a young woman named Elara, whose laughter was as sweet as the juiciest melon. He poured his heart out to her, sharing his dreams of traveling the world and selling exotic fruits. When Elara unexpectedly left town without a word, Lennon was devastated, burying his pain beneath a mask of carefree charm.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they embarked on their first long journey as a travelling merchant, his rickety cart laden with a colorful assortment of fruits. He reveled in the freedom of the open road, the ever-changing scenery fueling his imagination. Yet, beneath the surface, a nagging emptiness lingered, a yearning for something more than the fleeting connections he forged along the way.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.

          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they discovered a hidden grove of wild berries, their plumpness bursting with sweetness. He carefully picked the ripest ones, arranging them into a beautiful display before offering them to his father. His father, impressed by Lennon's keen eye and entrepreneurial spirit, gave him a small pouch of coins, sparking a lifelong passion for the art of buying and selling.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they overheard two merchants arguing over the price of a crate of oranges. He listened intently, absorbing the nuances of their negotiation, the subtle shifts in tone, and the unspoken power dynamics at play. That night, he practiced haggling with his father, honing his skills and discovering a knack for persuasion.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their father to let them travel to a neighboring town to sell their own fruit. He meticulously planned his route, carefully selecting the ripest mangoes and peaches, and crafting a captivating story about their origin. The success of his first solo venture filled him with a sense of accomplishment and ignited a desire for independence.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they fell deeply in love with a young woman named Elara, whose laughter was as sweet as the juiciest melon. He poured his heart out to her, sharing his dreams of traveling the world and selling exotic fruits. When Elara unexpectedly left town without a word, Lennon was devastated, burying his pain beneath a mask of carefree charm.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they embarked on their first long journey as a travelling merchant, his rickety cart laden with a colorful assortment of fruits. He reveled in the freedom of the open road, the ever-changing scenery fueling his imagination. Yet, beneath the surface, a nagging emptiness lingered, a yearning for something more than the fleeting connections he forged along the way.

1895-09-12 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 2 coins
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • 2 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Della Plumstone is a talented pastry chef known for her innovative and delicious creations.

          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 3 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 4 coins
          (d) 5 coins
          (e) 2 coins
          Answer: (e)

    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: reject
    Active player

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 12 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell peaches at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. Della has offered 2 coins for the peaches.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 2 coins or reject it.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to reject Della's offer.

          Question: Would Lennon Figtree accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (b)

        • Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 2 coins or reject it.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00]
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they wandered away from their father's stall at the market, captivated by a troupe of travelling performers. He was mesmerized by their colorful costumes, their booming voices, and the way they could weave stories that transported him to faraway lands. From that day forward, Lennon began to see the world as a stage, and himself as a potential performer.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they discovered a hidden grove of wild berries, their plumpness bursting with sweetness. He carefully picked the ripest ones, arranging them into a beautiful display before offering them to his father. His father, impressed by Lennon's keen eye and entrepreneurial spirit, gave him a small pouch of coins, sparking a lifelong passion for the art of buying and selling.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they overheard two merchants arguing over the price of a crate of oranges. He listened intently, absorbing the nuances of their negotiation, the subtle shifts in tone, and the unspoken power dynamics at play. That night, he practiced haggling with his father, honing his skills and discovering a knack for persuasion.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their father to let them travel to a neighboring town to sell their own fruit. He meticulously planned his route, carefully selecting the ripest mangoes and peaches, and crafting a captivating story about their origin. The success of his first solo venture filled him with a sense of accomplishment and ignited a desire for independence.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they fell deeply in love with a young woman named Elara, whose laughter was as sweet as the juiciest melon. He poured his heart out to her, sharing his dreams of traveling the world and selling exotic fruits. When Elara unexpectedly left town without a word, Lennon was devastated, burying his pain beneath a mask of carefree charm.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they embarked on their first long journey as a travelling merchant, his rickety cart laden with a colorful assortment of fruits. He reveled in the freedom of the open road, the ever-changing scenery fueling his imagination. Yet, beneath the surface, a nagging emptiness lingered, a yearning for something more than the fleeting connections he forged along the way.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Scene 2 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, my dear, how about 3 shillings for this fine bushel of apples?
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, my dear, how about 3 shillings for this fine bushel of apples?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, my dear, how about 3 shillings for this fine bushel of apples?
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, my dear, how about 3 shillings for this fine bushel of apples?
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions

          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.', '[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
        TimeDisplay

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, my dear, how about 3 shillings for this fine bushel of apples?
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could offer a price to Della Plumstone, try to convince her of the fruit's quality, or walk away from the negotiation.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to offer a price to Della Plumstone.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Cedric Meadowbrook likely to say next? Respond in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, my dear, how about 3 shillings for this fine bushel of apples?
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook could offer a price to Della Plumstone, try to convince her of the fruit's quality, or walk away from the negotiation.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he threw a tantrum of epic proportions when his parents refused to buy him a particularly ornate toy wagon. He cried until his face was red and his voice was hoarse, refusing to eat his supper until his parents finally relented, proving to him, once again, that his desires were paramount.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he convinced the local butcher to give him a handful of the finest sausages for free, simply by complimenting the butcher's apron and declaring that he had never seen such a well-kept shop. He savored the sausages, relishing not only the taste but also the power he wielded over others.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he organized a play in the village square, casting himself as the hero who saved the day from a fearsome dragon. He insisted on elaborate costumes and scenery, demanding the villagers participate in his theatrical masterpiece. The villagers, charmed by his enthusiasm, complied, further fueling Cedric's belief in his own importance.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced a neighboring farmer to trade him a basket of apples for a handful of pebbles, claiming the pebbles were enchanted and would bring good fortune. The farmer, superstitious and easily swayed by Cedric's persuasive words, readily agreed, leaving Cedric with a smug sense of satisfaction.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he traveled to a nearby town and set up a small fruit stall, using his charm and silver tongue to entice customers. He quickly learned the art of the deal, bartering and negotiating with a confidence that belied his age, and for the first time, tasted the sweet nectar of financial success.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he secured a deal with a wealthy merchant to supply him with exotic fruits from distant lands. He saw it as a stepping stone to greater things, a chance to build an empire of fruit and establish himself as a man of influence and power.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

        • 1895-09-13 00:00:00

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those apples look lovely, but I can only offer 2 shillings and sixpence. My customers back home are eager for a taste of Fruitville's finest, but they're not willing to pay top dollar.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those apples look lovely, but I can only offer 2 shillings and sixpence. My customers back home are eager for a taste of Fruitville's finest, but they're not willing to pay top dollar.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, my dear, how about 3 shillings for this fine bushel of apples?


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those apples look lovely, but I can only offer 2 shillings and sixpence. My customers back home are eager for a taste of Fruitville's finest, but they're not willing to pay top dollar.
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone

    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those apples look lovely, but I can only offer 2 shillings and sixpence. My customers back home are eager for a taste of Fruitville's finest, but they're not willing to pay top dollar.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Della Plumstone? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation??
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a whimsical inventor known for her peculiar gadgets.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Della Plumstone in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a renowned archaeologist on the verge of a groundbreaking discovery.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Della Plumstone to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Della Plumstone sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a talented pastry chef with a dream of opening her own bakery.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those apples look lovely, but I can only offer 2 shillings and sixpence. My customers back home are eager for a taste of Fruitville's finest, but they're not willing to pay top dollar.

          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she convinced the village children that a patch of wild berries were enchanted, capable of granting wishes. She charged them each a shiny pebble for a handful, pocketing a small fortune in trinkets.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she discovered a crate of bruised apples behind the village market. She cleaned them, arranged them artfully, and sold them as a rare, exotic variety to unsuspecting housewives.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she set up her first fruit stall at a bustling market. She charmed customers with tall tales about the origins of her produce, selling ordinary apples and pears at exorbitant prices.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she traveled to a distant city, her cart laden with fruit. She invented a story about a rare orchard, hidden deep in a forest, where the fruit possessed magical properties.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 5 coins

      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is attempting to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. Della has offered 2 shillings and sixpence for a bushel of apples.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those apples look lovely, but I can only offer 2 shillings and sixpence. My customers back home are eager for a taste of Fruitville's finest, but they're not willing to pay top dollar.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 2 shillings and sixpence for the bushel of apples or reject the offer and attempt to negotiate a higher price.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject Della's offer and attempt to negotiate a higher price.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (b)
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 2 shillings and sixpence for the bushel of apples or reject the offer and attempt to negotiate a higher price.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he threw a tantrum of epic proportions when his parents refused to buy him a particularly ornate toy wagon. He cried until his face was red and his voice was hoarse, refusing to eat his supper until his parents finally relented, proving to him, once again, that his desires were paramount.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he convinced the local butcher to give him a handful of the finest sausages for free, simply by complimenting the butcher's apron and declaring that he had never seen such a well-kept shop. He savored the sausages, relishing not only the taste but also the power he wielded over others.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he organized a play in the village square, casting himself as the hero who saved the day from a fearsome dragon. He insisted on elaborate costumes and scenery, demanding the villagers participate in his theatrical masterpiece. The villagers, charmed by his enthusiasm, complied, further fueling Cedric's belief in his own importance.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced a neighboring farmer to trade him a basket of apples for a handful of pebbles, claiming the pebbles were enchanted and would bring good fortune. The farmer, superstitious and easily swayed by Cedric's persuasive words, readily agreed, leaving Cedric with a smug sense of satisfaction.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he traveled to a nearby town and set up a small fruit stall, using his charm and silver tongue to entice customers. He quickly learned the art of the deal, bartering and negotiating with a confidence that belied his age, and for the first time, tasted the sweet nectar of financial success.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he secured a deal with a wealthy merchant to supply him with exotic fruits from distant lands. He saw it as a stepping stone to greater things, a chance to build an empire of fruit and establish himself as a man of influence and power.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, my dear, how about 3 shillings for this fine bushel of apples?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those apples look lovely, but I can only offer 2 shillings and sixpence. My customers back home are eager for a taste of Fruitville's finest, but they're not willing to pay top dollar.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:10:00.


          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is attempting to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. Della has offered 2 shillings and sixpence for a bushel of apples.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those apples look lovely, but I can only offer 2 shillings and sixpence. My customers back home are eager for a taste of Fruitville's finest, but they're not willing to pay top dollar.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 2 shillings and sixpence for the bushel of apples or reject the offer and attempt to negotiate a higher price.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Scene 4 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These apples are the finest in Fruitville, crisp and juicy, perfect for a pie or a midday snack.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These apples are the finest in Fruitville, crisp and juicy, perfect for a pie or a midday snack.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, my dear, how about 3 shillings for this fine bushel of apples?
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those apples look lovely, but I can only offer 2 shillings and sixpence. My customers back home are eager for a taste of Fruitville's finest, but they're not willing to pay top dollar.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These apples are the finest in Fruitville, crisp and juicy, perfect for a pie or a midday snack.

      • Instructions

          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit seller in Fruitville who is trying to sell his produce at the market. He has had difficulty negotiating prices with potential buyers, Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit seller in Fruitville who is trying to sell his produce at the market. He has had difficulty negotiating prices with potential buyers, Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can continue negotiating with Lennon Figtree, try to find another buyer, or pack up his fruit and leave the market.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to continue negotiating with Lennon Figtree.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Cedric Meadowbrook likely to say next? Respond in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These apples are the finest in Fruitville, crisp and juicy, perfect for a pie or a midday snack.
        AvailableOptionsPerception

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he threw a tantrum of epic proportions when his parents refused to buy him a particularly ornate toy wagon. He cried until his face was red and his voice was hoarse, refusing to eat his supper until his parents finally relented, proving to him, once again, that his desires were paramount.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he convinced the local butcher to give him a handful of the finest sausages for free, simply by complimenting the butcher's apron and declaring that he had never seen such a well-kept shop. He savored the sausages, relishing not only the taste but also the power he wielded over others.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he organized a play in the village square, casting himself as the hero who saved the day from a fearsome dragon. He insisted on elaborate costumes and scenery, demanding the villagers participate in his theatrical masterpiece. The villagers, charmed by his enthusiasm, complied, further fueling Cedric's belief in his own importance.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced a neighboring farmer to trade him a basket of apples for a handful of pebbles, claiming the pebbles were enchanted and would bring good fortune. The farmer, superstitious and easily swayed by Cedric's persuasive words, readily agreed, leaving Cedric with a smug sense of satisfaction.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he traveled to a nearby town and set up a small fruit stall, using his charm and silver tongue to entice customers. He quickly learned the art of the deal, bartering and negotiating with a confidence that belied his age, and for the first time, tasted the sweet nectar of financial success.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he secured a deal with a wealthy merchant to supply him with exotic fruits from distant lands. He saw it as a stepping stone to greater things, a chance to build an empire of fruit and establish himself as a man of influence and power.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I'll give you 4 coins for a basket. That's a fair price, considering I'm buying in bulk.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I'll give you 4 coins for a basket. That's a fair price, considering I'm buying in bulk.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins and not a penny more, Lennon. These peaches will be bruised by nightfall if you don't come down on the price.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. They're the finest peaches in Fruitville, plump and juicy. Three coins, and we have ourselves a deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Della, my dear, how about 3 shillings for this fine bushel of apples?
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, those apples look lovely, but I can only offer 2 shillings and sixpence. My customers back home are eager for a taste of Fruitville's finest, but they're not willing to pay top dollar.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These apples are the finest in Fruitville, crisp and juicy, perfect for a pie or a midday snack.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I'll give you 4 coins for a basket. That's a fair price, considering I'm buying in bulk.

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
